howItWorks.title: How to Calculate Slope (Gradient) Between Two Points
howItWorks.description: The slope (gradient) of a line is the measure of its steepness, calculated as the ratio of vertical change to horizontal change between any two points on the line. It represents how much y changes for each unit change in x.

tips: Positive slope means the line rises from left to right (increasing function)
Negative slope means the line falls from left to right (decreasing function)
Zero slope indicates a horizontal line (constant function)
Undefined slope occurs when x₂ = x₁ (vertical line)
The steeper the line, the larger the absolute value of the slope
Slope is independent of which point you choose as (x₁, y₁) or (x₂, y₂)
